body_html:
Could you run the following command? That flag is a lowercase L. This will tell you what the built-in rpath of that libcaffe2.dylib is.
otool -l /Users/hzq/Documents/www/test/libtorch/lib/libcaffe2.dylib | grep LC_RPATH -A2

Can you also echo LD_LIBRARY_PATH and DYLD_LIBRARY_PATH? These are the system rpath settings.

This shouldn't involve Python, I don't think. Though, if you use Anaconda or virtualenvs and this is in a virtualenv then it may add another some/env/lib folder to your path which might affect things.

Where is your mkl installed?

otool -l /Users/hzq/Documents/www/test/libtorch/lib/libcaffe2.dylib | grep LC_RPATH -A2
Can you also echo LD_LIBRARY_PATH and DYLD_LIBRARY_PATH? These are the system rpath settings.
This shouldn't involve Python, I don't think. Though, if you use Anaconda or virtualenvs and this is in a virtualenv then it may add another some/env/lib folder to your path which might affect things.
Where is your mkl installed?
body:
Could you run the following command? That flag is a lowercase L. This will tell you what the built-in rpath of that libcaffe2.dylib is. 
`otool -l /Users/hzq/Documents/www/test/libtorch/lib/libcaffe2.dylib | grep LC_RPATH -A2`

Can you also echo LD_LIBRARY_PATH and DYLD_LIBRARY_PATH? These are the system rpath settings.

This shouldn't involve Python, I don't think. Though, if you use Anaconda or virtualenvs and this is in a virtualenv then it may add another some/env/lib folder to your path which might affect things.

Where is your mkl installed?
